Title:
High diversity of Cytospora associated with canker and
dieback of Rosaceae in China, with ten new species described
Keywords:
Cytosporaceae, Diaporthales, phylogeny, taxonomy, 10 new
taxa
Abstract:
Cytospora canker is a destructive disease of numerous
hosts and causes serious economic losses with a worldwide distribution.
Identification of Cytospora species is difficult due to insufficient
phylogenetic understanding and overlapped morphological characteristics.
In this study, 48 fungal strains which covered nine genera of Rosaceae
were isolated from branches or twigs with symptomatic canker and dieback
disease in China. Through morphological observation and multilocus
phylogeny of ITS, LSU, act, rpb2, tef1-Î± and tub2 gene regions,
indicating 21 distinct lineages with high branch support. These include
10 Cytospora species were new, i.e., C. cinnamon, C. cotoneastricola, C.
ochreae, C. olivaceae, C. pruni-mume, C. roseae, C. rosicola, C.
royalae, C. sorbina, C. tibetensis, and 11 known taxa include Cytospora
erumpens, C. japonica, C. leucosperma, C. leucostoma, C. mali, C.
parasitica, C. populinopsis, C. schulzeri, C. sibiraeae, C. spiraeae and
C. tamaricicola. This study provides an initial understanding of the
taxonomy of Cytospora associated with canker and dieback disease of
Rosaceae in China.
